article.description: Ronny Turiaf scored 22 points and No. 8 Gonzaga beat Pepperdine 93-73 on Thursday night for its 11th consecutive win.
article.headline: Annual grudge match no contest at Kennel
article.linkText: Turiaf, Zags cruise past rival Pepperdine
article.story: SPOKANE, Wash. (AP) -- Ronny Turiaf knows how intimidating Gonzaga can be at home. Turiaf scored 22 points and the eighth-ranked Bulldogs beat Pepperdine 93-73 on Thursday night for their 11th consecutive win. Gonzaga built an 18-5 lead behind eight early points from Turiaf and cruised from there. "When we play like that and the Kennel goes crazy, it's tough for other teams to get going," said Turiaf, who shot 7-of-9 from the field and made all eight of his free throws. He scored 16 points in the first half, when Gonzaga shot 70 percent (19-of-27) to build a 50-36 lead. Blake Stepp added 18 points, 16 in the second half, for Gonzaga (18-2, 8-0 West Coast Conference), now 21-0 at home when ranked. Stepp added eight assists. Pepperdine (9-14, 4-4) has been Gonzaga's closest rival in the WCC in recent years, winning the league crown in 2000 and sharing it with Gonzaga in 2002. But the Waves have now lost nine of their past 10 against the Bulldogs. "They're together. They have experience. They have depth," Pepperdine coach Paul Westphal said. "They have an inside and an outside game." Yakhouba Diawara, in his sixth game since resolving NCAA eligibility issues, led Pepperdine with 24 points. In a battle of the top two offenses in the WCC, Gonzaga held Pepperdine to 44 percent shooting (28-of-63) and outrebounded the Waves 36-26. Gonzaga also had nine steals. Cory Violette added 13 points and 11 rebounds for Gonzaga, while Sean Mallon made all four of his field goals and all four free throws for 12 points. Adam Morrison also scored 12 for the Bulldogs, who finished the game shooting 57.9 percent (33-of-57). They also sank 23 of 25 free throws. "Our defense is very poor and their defense is very, very good," Westphal said. Pepperdine made a 12-2 run late in the first half to close to 41-30. The teams traded baskets in the second half, with Pepperdine unable to make up ground even as Gonzaga's shooting cooled off. Terrance Johnson scored seven of his 17 points during an 11-2 run as Pepperdine closed to 66-57 with 10:46 left. But the Waves kept sending Gonzaga to the free throw line, with Stepp hitting three to rebuild the Bulldogs' lead to 73-61. Stepp hit a 3-pointer and two free throws, and Erroll Knight and Morrison added baskets as Gonzaga took an 86-67 lead with 3 minutes left to seal it. "They're tough to play anywhere," Johnson said. "They don't break down." Gonzaga stayed close with WCC rivals in the first half of the previous four games, and did not want to do that against a Pepperdine team capable of putting up a lot of points. "The coaches wanted us coming out with high energy," Turiaf said. Despite Gonzaga's recent run of wins, the games against Pepperdine are always emotional, Stepp said, and the 4,000 fans packed into the Kennel were extremely loud. "Pepperdine is such a big game every year," Stepp said. "We always feed off this crowd." Saint Joseph's and Stanford, the only remaining undefeated teams in Division I, handed Gonzaga its only losses this season. Gonzaga is 146-10 at home the past 12 seasons.
